metadata.case_name: Petitioner Company v. State of Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: Petitioner is a company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, registered office at Kanpur, Uttar Pradesh, carrying on business in manufacture and sale of jute goods.
Under U.P. Sales Tax Act No. XV of 1948 (Principal Act, in force April 1, 1948), notification dated June 8, 1948 imposed tax of six pies in the rupee on sale of jute under s. 3-A.

Section 3-A(1) of U.P. Sales Tax Act 1948 as on March 31, 1956 allowed State Government by notification to declare single point taxation and specify rate not exceeding one anna per rupee for listed goods or nine pies for others.
Governor of Uttar Pradesh issued Ordinance No. IX of 1956 on March 31, 1956 under Art. 213(1), published same date, substituting s. 3-A(2) to allow tax up to one anna per rupee on all goods.

Notification No. ST. 905/X dated March 31, 1956 issued under s. 3-A as amended, superseding previous, declaring turnover of jute goods liable to tax at one anna per rupee from April 1, 1956 at single point (importer/manufacturer).

Impugned notification superseded by fresh notification on August 1, 1956; dispute relates to tax on sales between April 1, 1956 and July 31, 1956; tax per notification Rs. 1,26,529-3-0, half if invalid.
U.P. Sales Tax Amendment Act XIX of 1956 replaced Ordinance No. IX of 1956, came into force May 28, 1956, deemed effective from April 1, 1956.
Allahabad High Court in Adarsh Bhandar v. Sales Tax Officer (AIR 1957 All 475) struck down notification as unauthorised since s. 3-A effective only from April 1, 1956.
U.P. Sales Tax Amendment Act XXIV of 1957 assented August 31, 1957, published September 3, 1957, amended Act XIX of 1956 to deem s. 3-A effective from March 31, 1956.

Allahabad High Court Full Bench in Firm Bangali Mal v. Sales Tax Officer (AIR 1958 All 478) held Amendment Act XXIV of 1957 conferred power retrospectively but did not validate the specific notification issued under prior power.

U.P. Sales Tax Validation Act XV of 1958 (assented May 3, 1958, published May 6, 1958) validated notifications in Schedule including No. ST. 905/X under s. 3, deeming sections in force on issuance date as before commencement.
Petitioner filed writ petition under Art. 32 contending notification continues void despite Validation Act, and Act ultra vires.

legal_issues.text: Whether on true construction, the U.P. Sales Tax Validation Act XV of 1958 validates the impugned notification No. ST. 905/X dated March 31, 1956.
Whether the Validation Act is ultra vires the State legislature's powers under Entry 54 List II Seventh Schedule as retrospective sales tax legislation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Validation Act does not validate impugned notification as words 'in the form in which they were in force immediately before the commencement of this Act' qualify notifications, not sections, subjecting it to same infirmity.

Validation Act ultra vires as sales tax under Entry 54 List II must be on occasion of sale; retrospective tax (sales 1956, Act 1958) not tax on sale; indirect tax cannot be passed on retrospectively; inconsistent with U.P. Sales Tax Act ss. 8A, 14, Rule 63 requiring pre-sale collection.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 54 List II; Province of Madras v. Boddu Paidanna

respondent_arguments.text: Validation Act expressly validates impugned notification listed in Schedule Part B; words qualify sections, not notifications; Hindi version confirms; retrospective operation valid for sales tax under Entry 54.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 3 Validation Act; Tata Iron & Steel Co. v. State of Bihar

respondent_arguments.text: State legislature has plenary power under Entry 54 to impose tax on past sales prospectively or retrospectively; not essential for sales tax to be pass-on-able; provisions of U.P. Sales Tax Act do not limit legislative competence.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 54 List II; M.P.V. Sundararamier & Co. v. State of A.P.

court_reasoning.text: Words 'in the form in which they were in force immediately before the commencement of this Act' in s. 3 Validation Act qualify 'sections', not 'notifications'; preamble and Schedule show intent to validate; Hindi version confirms; Allahabad HC in H.L.M. Biri Works agreed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature avowedly validated notification; construction avoiding failure of object preferred.

court_reasoning.text: Sales tax under Entry 54 on legal sales; plenary power includes retrospective levy; 'occasion of sale' refers to transaction character, not time of levy; not essential to pass on tax.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tata Iron & Steel holds sales tax nature unchanged even if not passed on; sovereign legislature power prospective/retrospective.

court_reasoning.text: Provisions like ss. 8A, 14, Rule 63 of U.P. Sales Tax Act concern machinery, not competence; do not prevent retrospective validation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sundararamier: lack of machinery does not negate imposition.

holdings.text: U.P. Sales Tax Validation Act XV of 1958 validly validates impugned notification No. ST. 905/X dated March 31, 1956.
Validation Act intra vires Entry 54 List II despite retrospective operation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Adarsh Bhandar v. Sales Tax Officer

precedents_cited.case_name: Firm Bangali Mal v. Sales Tax Officer
precedents_cited.relevance: Held Amendment Act XXIV/1957 conferred power but did not validate specific notification.

precedents_cited.case_name: Province of Madras v. Boddu Paidanna and Sons
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Occasion of sale' distinguishes sales tax from excise; does not bar retrospectivity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sales Tax Officer v. Messrs. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash
precedents_cited.relevance: Tax on agreement to sell outside Entry 54.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co. (Madras) Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Tax on works contract supply as sale ultra vires.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tata Iron & Steel Co. Ltd. v. State of Bihar

precedents_cited.relevance: Retrospective validation of inter-state sales tax valid; machinery provisions irrelevant to competence.

precedents_cited.case_name: H.L.M. Biri Works v. Sales Tax Officer

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Imposed single point tax; amended retrospectively; provisions for collection do not limit legislative power.

U.P. Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1957 (Act XXIV)
U.P. Sales Tax Validation Act, 1958 (Act XV)

statutes_cited.relevance: Writ jurisdiction; Governor's ordinance power; parliamentary override on inter-state sales; state power on sales tax.

outcome.summary: Held U.P. Sales Tax Validation Act XV of 1958 intra vires and validates notification No. ST. 905/X dated March 31, 1956; impugned notification valid; petitioner liable to pay tax at one anna per rupee for period April 1 to July 31, 1956.

key_quotes.text: The object of the legislation as stated in the long title and in the preamble to the Act was to validate the impugned notification in relation to the amended section.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects petitioner's construction argument on Validation Act.

key_quotes.text: Whether a law should be enacted, imposing a sales tax, or validating the imposition of sales tax, when the seller is not in a position to pass it on to the consumer, is a matter of policy and does not affect the competence of the legislature.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Upholds retrospective validation despite pass-on issue.

key_quotes.text: The power of a legislature to enact a law with reference to a topic entrusted to it... is... unqualified subject only to any limitation imposed by the Constitution. In the exercise of such a power, it will be competent for the legislature to enact a law, which is either prospective or retrospective.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on legislative competence for retrospective sales tax.
